The core idea here is you place cubes into regions and then those cubes become worth points based on how many of the issue cards in that region align to the issue cards in front of you. For having the most points in a region, you also get the special reward of trying to groom the endgame scoring requirements to match what issues you want them to be. The game has some decent amount of flip luck, and planning too much to set up future turns has a way of backfiring pretty easily as players slip the issues cards, and your multipliers out from under you. Ultimately I found this game a little too complicated, chaotic and long.

First impressions:

- An area control game at it's heart. Winning an "area" involves gaining the most rally cubes (and trend) and also maximizing the number of matching cards for that region.

- The main phases of the game are very procedural to the point of being tedious to run through every round.

- Turn order is hugely important in most phases. Since the first player is dictated by a blind bid, it make no sense why the turn order isn't in order of who spent the most money. This could potentially result in the second place bid being last in turn order which could completely deny the ability to take actions in the round like play a media marker or play a cabinet card. This feels like a huge flaw in the game and feels unsatisfying to play.

- The opinion poll cards also feel very out of place because it directly punishes two random players. The main reason you buy a poll card is to increase your own trend, but that action also drags two random players down. Since trend is a hard resource to get, it feels like a bad design choice again.

- For such a long and procedural game, there are one too many random elements making it not that fun to play. I do love the setting and the thematic integration of most mechanisms.

Die Macher shows how far euro games have come. Its an incredibly overdrawn game that has far too many systems layered upon each other. The game is also highly procedural, making the protracted play time insufferable, as even small decisions take several minutes to play out. The shadow cabinet and polling cards are neat ideas, but are drowned beneath the menagerie of auxiliary mechanisms. The game also implements blind bidding in an unfortunate way, and has far too many random elements for a game of its length. While I'm sure Die Macher was the cream of the crop decades ago, but now it feels antiquated and obsoleted by modern game designs.

There's a lot of cool elements to like in this game, but it also shows its heritage of one of the first proto-Euro style games.

Namely, there is a lot of randomness going on still, in an otherwise strategic and lengthy game. Your goal is to gain votes, but getting votes has to do with aligning your party platform to a region, gaining popularity in that region, and getting members in that region. The issue is your party platform is partially determined by random card draws, so you can't match if you don't draw the right cards, and your popularity track is partially determined by random poll results that may be what you need or not.

Which means doing well and winning comes down a little to player decisions, and a lot to the luck of being able to position yourself in the right way. This may be (and is) an excellent commentary on politics, but it doesn't make for fun game mechanics.

I've heard that various editions and house rules mitigate a lot of this as over the years the designer and others take ideas from more modern designs that have learned some things, and I think Die Macher likely would benefit from ways to further reduce and mitigate the randomness of these and other elements.

If those succeed, I think the rest of the game is pretty fun and the theme comes through pretty strong. The gameplay is interesting as everyone is rationing their resources in order to fight all these various elections and make sure you can afford the various things you need to.

The game I played though that's the final issue--because you get money also from winning seats, if you get poor early alignment on issues and poll results, you get far less cash too, and so it feels far too swingy to be a proper great strategy game, and why am I spending 3ish hours playing a game asking me to do all this resource management and planning if the main thing picking the winner isn't our decision making, but instead the luck of the draws?

2022 Update: this is a game to which time has not been kind. We played it endlessly back in the 90s and a bit into the early aughts, but after a couple plays in the mid-2010s I just have zero desire to return to it. It’s long, it’s punishing, it’s capricious, it’s fiddly, and the rules for winning “by a nose” have never worked satisfactorily despite trying a few variations. Tribune has a somewhat similar political flavor from this same designer, and is a game that *has* held up reasonably well to the onslaught of modern games so I’d check that one out.

I keep waffling my rating a bit on this one, between a 7 and an 8. I really like the challenge of the game, all the tough and interesting choices it confronts you with, and the fact that it feels really thematic as you try to figure out which regions your party will run well in and how you can change your party platform to please the voters. What I don't like is the fact that the luck of the draw on the polls and the platform cards seems a bit too heavy given the weight and length of the game.

On the one hand, thematically, these luck elements feel right. You shouldn't be able to arbitrarily change your party's platform all the time, and voters are often unpredictable. But, this is a long game (5-6 hours), and one with a lot of energy and emotional investment, and yet one that can turn on a single poll card or getting good platform draws. I guess I just wish the game were just a bit shorter. At 5 hours, this is the same length as Revolution, Successors, or Civilization (with 5), and I don't feel that it's nearly as rewarding as those games.
---
Note: We always play with a house rule that if the 80-seat region comes out in the initial 4 elections, we replace it. This region (which was added in the 1996-ish Hans-im-Gluck reprint and not the original) could, and probably should, be removed from the game.
---
Edition Note: There are now 3 versions of the game, the original (and now very hard-to-find) Moskito edition, the updated Hans-im-Gluck version, and the Valley Games reprint of the Hans-im-Gluck edition. The big differences are between the Moskito and HiG versions; the latter version supports a fifth player, has fewer restrictions on the parties, and a couple other minor rule changes I don't specifically recall. The Valley Games version has updated issues and slightly more internationally-friendly cards.

Probably the Hans-im-Gluck version is the best; it's graphically the most professional and functional (some of the CG illustrations in the Valley Games version are cheesy), and while there is German on some of the cards, it's not a big deal. The Valley Games edition is of slightly lower printing quality and some of the symbols on the issue cards are strange (although some of the complaints I've heard seem overblown). The Valley Games version does have a more sensibly-sized box, though!

Die Macher as a game that is over 30 years old and still played is an example of another time in gaming. Today, the game lacks a certain pizzazz that newer heavy euros have (not just in theme, but mechanical implementation) and it's more difficult to hold the attention of players. I can see where those who put in the effort to look past the points where modern gamers would say "this really should be streamlined" and study of the design will be rewarded.

In some ways, it's a game that falls into the same category as Virgin Queen/HiS and the COIN series; long, hulking, beautiful monstrosities that require a full player count to shine. Bonus points if they are all experienced folks. People have to rearrange their lives and schedules to make these sorts of games happen. Die Macher is a wonderful convention game, provided people have agree on a rule set... Unfortunately, that boat seems to have sailed, and the 4th edition is also unlikely to resolve that. That's not necessarily bad, just an annoyance.

This is an experience, one of those games that was revolutionary at it's time, and I encourage people to give it a shot. I'd like to sit and tinker with it, to explore how the interlocking pieces and parts all fit together, but at what cost? Do I need a copy on hand? I doubt it, possibly just nearby. Every now and then I think about it, even if it took years to get it to the table, and I'm unsure when I'll see it played again...

edit: The more I fiddle with and talk about the game with others, the more I find that it's just undercooked, and you have to cobble together an agreeable ruleset in order to get it to really sing. I don't think that's worth my time anymore.

Extremely heavy game and too mathy for me. I also find the eye-gouging in this game to be too extreme and very unfair. You can spend four turns and multiple actions building up your position in one zone only to have all that hard work completely undone with a single action from another player that is impossible for you to stop, and this happens time after time throughout the game. Plays far too long also.

There are some interesting things going on in this game (the ability to plan ahead in future elections, for instance), but there is an awful lot of card-based luck in terms of candidate platforms, polls/trends, and card-related scoring. Also, if you do very poorly in the first election (which is a money election), you're already at a fairly decent disadvantage. I may play this again, but I may not.

So let's start with the bad. All the little calculations in this game are tedious and obnoxious to make (more so than in any 18xx I've played). Calculating Factor is especially bad, but going around the table parsing each player's platform to score their National Issue matches is a close second. The rules are fiddly and the game is borderline unteachable without a good player aid (there is luckily a pretty good one in the files section here by user k1mm1ngs). Even with the improved iconography of the second edition, simply identifying matches and mismatches is draining. End game is a chore and prolly took us 10 minutes. Placements for Media and Meeting markers felt obvious, but that could just be lack of creativity on our part (for one we never used our shadow cabinet card to hurt other parties so we certainly missed out on something).

But there was a lot to love here. The negotiation felt really great; we permitted money to exchange hands and I loved how one emergent strategy was to partner up with other players to agree on how much to let poll cards go for (or even split the costs). Coalitions are one of the coolest mechanisms, especially how you can manipulate your platform to force or encourage coalitions. I get slight vibes of El Grande's GOPS system in how you balance early money and late game bonus die rolls, and it's sublime. It's fascinating how turn order can be both a boon and a bane, and how important it is to correctly navigate it.

This game has more than its fair share of randomness with the die rolls, hidden poll cards, and and draws for platform and opinion cards, but none of it felt especially bad to me. If anything, I appreciated the uncertainty and push-your-luck/mitigation elements it brings to the game; the poll cards are especially dramatic, and I love that at times it caused people to absolutely lose their minds in the auction (and then face palm immediately up seeing the card for themselves).

I really do need to play it once more to see how strategies develop and see how the upkeep and maintenance hold up with a little more experience. It's also a bit long and repetitive. Our session ran long for extraneous reasons, but it felt engaging anyways. If it reliably went four hours, that's prolly fine for this game.

My rating is probably too low; I partly feel like I should hold off rating until I play another game of it. But this feels like a "like it, don't love it" situation. It is very Euro-y for sure. Very long, and a lot of balls to keep in the air. Closest comp for me would be Dominant Species, which is more complicated, but which I liked more; both have a very no-frills approach to visual design, which I'm not crazy about. Die Macher is very, very fluid, almost abstract, more so than I expected. I would have liked to see a little more stability, a little more cross-over from one election to another. Given the time commitment and the need for at least 4 players, I can't see myself playing it very often; if I'm going to play one game for 4 hours, it'll probably be Arkham Horror. But playing another game where I know what I'm doing from the get-go would be helpful. Consider the rating provisional.

Mechanics are intertwined across turns and between parties, enabling levers for manipulation but at the cost of excessive complication. Graphics and user interface are dated, obstructing gameplay. Too procedural and suitable for table that prefer to negotiate for every advantage which then lead to long game time.

Played with people who already know the rules, and played quickly, this is a game I would almost always be willing to play. There is almost no downtime as each player makes many small decisions concurrently with each other to move through the 11 (11!), but tiny, phases of the turn. And, each decision matters and can have a bad word inducing impact on the other players - no multi-player solitaire here. I wouldn't want to play the game all the time - it's mentally taxing - but I'll still look forward to seeing it hit the table again sometime in the future.

It takes time to come to grips with the many and varied moving parts that is the engine called Die Macher. It's what I imagine trying to fly a helicopter would be like - every adjustment affects some other system which then needs to be adjusted, which affects another system, and so on.... An exhausting but thoroughly entertaining ride.

Gnarly and thematically rich, a rad look into the past. Waltzing through this with a German accent was a very enjoyable time, just not something I'd ever choose to pull out on my own, haha. The biggest thing that felt outdated and creaky was the card randomness, especially the way player policies worked. The options for state policy swaps often felt restricted and clogged, but trying to pivot on issues felt like a coin flip, and actually getting a card you want to pivot into felt impossible for me for the last three rounds. I can see the benefit to that in how it keeps players from simply forming a complete hive mind, but I just kept wishing there was a better way of doing that that also let me feel like I was able to actually make changes as needed. The ways you have to play around your policies are present, at least, so I do think it's partially on me not being as experienced with the game. Too bad I don't think that's going to progress anytime soon, haha.

Die Macher is a heavyweight Eurogame that plunges players into the intricacies of German federal elections, tasking them with managing national political parties across seven regional contests. It’s a sprawling, multi-layered experience where players must balance public opinion, media influence, party platforms, and resource management- all while jockeying for dominance in each region. The game’s complexity is legendary, but for those willing to invest the time, it delivers one of the most rewarding strategic arcs in board gaming.

Each round unfolds like a mini-campaign, with players adjusting their party stance to match regional issues, deploying activists, and leveraging media control to sway voters. The tension is palpable as you decide whether to go all-in on a region or strategically concede to focus elsewhere. The interplay between short-term tactics and long-term national strategy is razor-sharp, and the scoring system which is based on regional victories, media presence, and ideological alignment ensures that every decision matters.

What elevates Die Macher is its thematic integrity. It doesn’t just use politics as a backdrop... it feels political, with all the negotiation, compromise, and strategic posturing that entails. The game’s components and presentation may feel utilitarian by modern standards, but the mechanics more than make up for it. It’s best with 4–5 players who relish deep planning and interaction, and while the rules are dense, they’re surprisingly intuitive once the game gets rolling.

Die Macher is a towering achievement in strategic design. It’s not for the faint of heart, but for players who crave a rich, cerebral challenge with real-world resonance, it’s a must-play. A true classic that still holds its seat at the table of political strategy games.

Second game in and this is probably the best example of what modern tastes can't tolerate - great example of the nascent German mechanisms, still untouched by elegance, seasoned with relentless interference and interaction. 1st Edition
(Corrected games log: 2 plays, 03-08-07, 08-16-07)
The 1st edition of Macher is noticeably more of a rough-cut than the 2nd, but the game system is still recognizable, and the final product is still very fun. Everything that one would expect from the later version is here in spades: media control, shadow cabinet play, but the system is slightly less tuned and more opaque in many phases, particularly the conversion of meeting markers into votes, and the extremely convoluted final scoring.

I like playing this version of the game rather than the 2nd when we only have 4 players, mainly because the 1st seems to be slightly nastier and more effectively tuned for the 4 scale.

A rule that I particularly like is the way the party platform changes, here it is a completely deterministic, voluntary choice thing, and I would actually like to convert that rule to the 2nd edition, because I think it adds another interesting player choice into the mix without sacrificing anything in the process.

I will say though, the final scoring is a headache your first time through, and the scores seem positively gaudy when one is used to the later iteration of the system.

Masterful, deep, intriguing, there is nothing I can say negative about this game other than the fact that due to its political nature the scale should be a minimum 4. The 4 hours this takes feel like less than 1 to me, as it pulls me in completely. Hard to find a game with a more long term strategy element to it either, this will reward the person thinking 3 elections ahead time and time again with a big fat mandate and the score to show for it. The balance on this game is utterly superb as well, early election victories lead to more points for media markers, yet lower the number of national issues you're going to successfully dictate. Small elections might offer a small mandate, but they might be an easy way to push your agenda, or get your media on top. Control the media? Your agenda becomes the people's agenda. Cash in early chips and go for an absolute majority to further your own ends? Or hold out and try to push that multiplier a little bit higher? Absolutely everything I'm looking for in a game...

Scale is by far and away best with 5, though I am willing to play it with 4. With 3, the game just loses too much to be worth pulling out.

On an aside, I prefer to play this with the following variants:
- Flood Rule --> Nigh compulsory, important for media value.
- Shifting National Opinion Rule --> Also nigh compulsory, rewards long term issue presence, keeps late changes from being even more powerful.
- Money can change hands --> My softest preference, but I do like it. Can add some intrigue at times.

Notes on the 3rd Edition (Valley Games):

A minus for the graphical design on the cards, a plus for the graphical design on the boards. Some of the issue cards are too similar for their own good, and are harder to tell apart at a distance than the HiG edition. On the plus, the icons for where the region card / shadow cabinet cards / coalition tiles should go is a nice add.

The rules changes are brutal though:
I played this once with the exchange pool rules as written (i.e.: pool starts at 6, no way to actually add cards to it, it just stays at 6 with cards rotating in and out based on media control) and didn't care for the restriction that it placed on the media. I would lobby actively against playing with the rule again and would likely opt out of playing it if a majority wanted to play with it.

The short game rules are an atrocity and I would not be willing to play the game with them. They cut off a chunk of the game's long term planning and excise, perhaps, 1-1.5 hours at most from play, a tiny time savings for the kind of things they remove.

I can see why this game is #1 in the BGG database. I find this to be an almost perfect design. It's rules light but very strategically deep. There is math involved, but it's not Arkwright levels of math. You can plan ahead. There's randomness, but you can mitigate it by either winning auctions or being the media lead in each state election. The only complaint is that it runs long for the full game (~4 hours) and it looks ugly so I doubt my normal group would want to play it. But make no mistake, it's exceptional.

I ticked off this long-standing SoS game early in 2024 and it was a very strong first impression. For a game that looks this dry and with it's incredibly procedural lack of flow, Die Macher produced surprisingly consistent excitement at the table from start to finish.

With 5 first time players, the first round or two felt a bit like educated guesswork as we made incremental decisions in one phase and then braced ourselves for the fallout in the next. By the mid-point things were humming along nicely - nuanced negotiations, less nuanced lobbying, constantly shifting alliances, coalitions of the willing and the not so willing, and all sorts of excellent shenanigans that would have been oh-so-memorable if not for a theme that adheres so doggedly to the bureaucracy the game seeks to simulate.

The second game was even more thought provoking than the first. With a better understanding of the tools at our disposal, how to affect change and how quickly that change can come about, how and where to set up short and long term strategies, and a strong sense of the scoring, the game was tense and the contest hot from the word go. The push and pull dynamic of the forced coalitions and national board are a fantastic forecasting decision space and I can't imagine playing without them as per the rules in the newest edition. The strict limitations on media cubes, meeting markers, shadow cabinet cards and coalition markers ensures every choice is impactful and that the trade-offs on timing and assets need always be considered carefully - save the goodwill of your opponents, there are no catch-up mechanics in Die Macher and plenty of ways to shoot yourself in the foot.

I only expect the game to get better and more hotly contested with each successive play, I just need to make it happen. 10/10

I have now played this game a number of times. A very interesting system. It is very "full" (lots of tasks) to it takes someone with a wargamer background to be able to last. But every action by another player effects your own issues so is it like you are participating in another's turn.

Often when I have played this game two if not three of the players were new to the game; though some had tried to learn the rules in advance. The first game I played took six hours as well as the second game; the third took seven hours. In a forced game I could see going five hours but it is far nicer to pace one's self and just say it will take six (it has taken this long even with all players having played before).

It seems that the actual playing time can be faster, but when rules & setup time are added, this is a long game.

It is not super complicated as much as there are many steps in every turn making the process take time. Those new to the game get the grasp of it enough to make their decisions after one or two rounds (of six); though in every case they would have wanted to try things diffently if played again. THIS GAME IS MUCH BETTER WITH THE HELP SHEETS THAT CAN BE FOUND HERE AT BGG; they keep track of all the steps. I do think it takes playing once or twice in order to get the management of money & resources down so that a stratagy could be followed better during playing.

It is a most interesting way to set up an election game, still making me think the same format could be used to represent the primary process in American presidential elections.

I also have a copy of the original "blue box" edition which has only four parties and seems a little different in its structure. (I have never played this version.)

I also have the Valley Games printing but find the shorter five turn version ruins the game.

I also have the Spielworxx printing but have yet to use it.

超主观点评（5人局）：
1、代入感拉满了，党派方针要与公众舆论保持一致，但是控制媒体又可以直接影响公众舆论，好的幕僚更是可以直接让党派起飞，但是要请好的幕僚又很贵真的太真实了哈哈哈，公众教育、数字化、交通、社会福利等内容和生活也息息相关，很容易找到感觉。
2、玩法挺简单的，对着玩家提示板说一遍就可以开始，但是资源有限，各种行动又互相影响，思考量巨大，爽歪歪。虽然结算耗时蛮久，但是大家都很有参与感，不会无聊到找别的事情做。
3、输了就自己翻规则逆天改命的感觉真爽！纠出一个村点，第1名摆了2个媒体指示物到媒体板块，然后险胜2分哈哈哈！
4、2019年12月16日初玩印象非常糟糕，2025年2月9日再玩感觉非常上头，大家决定下周末再开两局，不知道是规则改进了（怀疑当时没有轮抽）还是当年没玩懂或者是纯属运气太差？当时玩的是旧版，感受还是留一下：一个非常看运气的游戏，起始手牌不好的话建议直接掀桌！玩一局要三至四个小时，第二把我们玩的时候有三家手牌高度一致，结果就变成二打三，无论如何都没办法翻盘，简直浪费时间！（6分）
小心得：
1、抢先手很重要，顺位靠前可以确保幕僚卡的感叹号可以用出来，几乎每个感叹号都很逆天。
2、钱没有那么重要，我们终局最高的159分，钱最多的才有6分太少了，而且钱是不公开的，再怎么省，自己的钱也不一定是最多的。
